become.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to start to have a feeling or quality, or to start to develop into something
become.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Slowly my eyes became accustomed to the darkness.
Helen became increasingly anxious about her husband’s strange behaviour.
Pollution from cars has become a major problem.
become.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to start to have a job or position
become.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: George became king at the age of 54.
When did you first want to become a teacher?
become.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to be suitable for someone, or to look attractive on them
become.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Don’t try to be clever – it doesn’t become you.
become.translation[0].note_box[0].items[: Become is a linking verb This type of verb links the subject of the sentence with an adjective or noun
She hoped to become a lawyer
become.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: to start to have a feeling or quality, or to start to develop into something
His parents became worried when he was late home from school.
Violent crime is becoming a major problem.
She became more confident when she joined a drama group.
to start to have a feeling or quality. Get  is less formal than become and is much more commonly used in everyday English
Make sure you’re home before it gets dark.
to become something – used about things becoming a different colour, or things or people becoming worse in some way
to become something – used about things becoming a different colour, or the weather or people’s behaviour changing
The water had turned bright green.
The weather is expected to turn cold again.
to become undone, loose, or separated into pieces
The caterpillar changed into a beautiful butterfly.
